title-group.article-title: Why Does Joseph Wash his Face?

fn.p: My thanks to Carolyn Sharp, Joel Baden, John Collins, John Darnell, H.G.M. Williamson, and the anonymous JSOT reviewer for their comments toward improving this article. I retain responsibility for any remaining errors. Additionally, my thanks to Baruch Schwartz for making his paper, ‘J and E in the Joseph Saga’ (unpublished paper presented at the Annual Meeting of the Society of Biblical Literature, New Orleans, November 2009), available for consultation. This article is a complete revision and rewriting of an S.T.M. thesis paper submitted to Yale Divinity School in December 2008. Portions of this article were presented in the Egyptology and Ancient Israel program of the Annual Meeting of the Society of Biblical Literature in San Francisco, November 2011.

abstract.p: Genesis 43.31a contains the only description of someone washing his or her face in the Hebrew Bible. Did the author purposefully select his words to signify a crucial junction in the narrative? Few examples from the biblical corpus and extra-biblical witnesses can be cited for comparison. Locating the narrative of Genesis 42–43 in its specific context, descriptions of face-washing from recovered Egyptian witnesses suggest that a foreign motif is the influence for the terse, yet precise, description of a Hebrew protagonist coping with his emotions in another part of the world.

sec.title: ‭זינפ ץחךיז‬: A Unique Description
sec.p: Genesis 43.29–31 portrays a scene from the second of two meetings between Joseph and his brothers in Egypt. Within these verses, Joseph's inability to control his emotions after seeing Benjamin (43.29–30) and his strength in regaining his composure (43.31b) provide abundant material for commentators. Little, if any, attention is directed towards the description of Joseph washing his face in Gen. 43.31a: ‘Then he washed his face’ (‭זינפ ץחךיז‬). The absence of significant commentary on this half-verse is not staggering—what else should the protagonist do after a good cry? And what else can Joseph do to hide his emotions from his brothers? Medieval rabbis do not discuss Joseph washing his face, and the omission could be explained by the lack of any significant solecisms or halakha in Gen. 43.31a. Modern commentators, for the most part, are interested in Joseph's psychological welfare.1 Should we, however, overlook this seemingly quotidian description of a person unwilling to reveal any emotion in front of his siblings?

I propose that the unique juxtaposition of two widely attested words in the biblical corpus, the verb ‭ץחך‬ (‘to wash’) and its object ‭םינפ‬ (‘face’), is noteworthy. Genesis 43.31a contains the only explicit description of anyone washing his or her face in the Hebrew Bible.2 Focusing on ‭ץחך‬ within the pentateuchal corpus, I shall note some of its descriptions.3 In order to prevent any defilement of Yhwh's earthly abode and its abandonment by the deity, P (the Priestly corpus) presents a multitude of scenarios that demand for a person to bathe in water.4 In contrast to the washing rituals described in P, J (the Yahwistic source) contains multiple accounts of a host inviting a sojourner to wash their feet (Gen. 18.4; 19.2; 24.32; 43.24) and the description of Joseph washing his face (43.31a).5 The uniqueness of Gen. 43.31a is accentuated in the Joseph Story. In the first of the brothers’ two visits to Egypt (chs. 42–44), Joseph recognizes his brothers, cries in private, and rejoins them (42.24).6 In the brothers’ second visit, Joseph recognizes Benjamin and, similar to the prior meeting, he cries in seclusion. Yet unlike the first encounter, Joseph washes his face before rejoining his brothers. A question arises from this discrepancy: Why does Joseph wash his face after the second time he cries but not the first? In other words, why did the author write this detail on only one of the two occasions?

Differences between the first and second meetings may offer an explanation. The sight of Benjamin in the second meeting might account for Gen. 43.31a, but is Benjamin that significant a figure for the phrase ‭ןינפ ץחךין‬ to occur at this junction of the Joseph Story? A more notable difference between the two accounts lies in Joseph's actions after he returns to his brothers. In the first meeting Joseph speaks to his brothers and confines Simeon (42.24b) but Joseph orders a meal in the second meeting (43.31b). Genesis 43.32b informs the reader that the Egyptians considered it an abomination to eat with Hebrews. In Lev. 22.5–6, H (the Holiness Code) requires one who contacts an unclean swarming thing or human being to wash his body in water before partaking in the ‭םישךק‬ meal. Put together, one could surmise that Joseph washes his face to purge himself of the uncleanliness caused by contact with his (‘foreign’) brothers before he can eat. There are, however, three notable problems with this proposal. First, if Joseph was to wash before a meal as required in Lev. 22.5–6, then we should expect him to wash his body ([‭תא‬] ‭ץחךין ןךשב‬) and not his face. Second, the description of food (‭םחל‬) in Gen. 43.31b can hardly be equated to H's ‭םישךק‬ meal. Third, the unclean person in Lev. 22.5 expands upon one afflicted with bodily impurities described in P (Lev. 12–15);7 in contrast, Joseph's brothers display no remarkable bodily impurities. Joseph washing his face as a purification ritual before a meal (along the lines of Lev. 22.5–6) is therefore suggestive but not entirely convincing. In Gen. 43.30–31, washing the face is more appropriate for someone who has cried, rather than for someone about to partake in a meal. Still, the meal itself remains a distinct feature of the second meeting and the placement of Gen. 43.31a within this pericope becomes apparent after a more thorough examination of the motif of face-washing.

How are we then to understand the seemingly mundane event of Joseph washing his face when it is the only explicit example in the Hebrew Bible? ‭ץחךין‬ in Gen. 43.31a continues a chain of waw-consecutives within a narrative sequence that begins in 43.29.8 We may expand the sample size by considering the causal relationship between ‭ץחךין‬ and the preceding waw-consecutive ‭דביו‬ in 43.30b. Two other narratives in the Hebrew Bible juxtapose these two verbs in close proximity. In Exod. 2.5–6, Pharaoh's daughter washes (‭ךאיה־לע ץחךל העךפ־תב ךךתו‬) and hears the child Moses crying (‭הככ‬). The relationship between ‭ץחך‬ and ‭ךאיה־לצ‬ in Exod. 2.5–6, however, lacks the causality in Gen. 43.30b-31a where the same person washes after crying. In 2 Sam. 12.20–21, after David is informed that the child born to Bathsheba is dead, he rises from the ground, washes, anoints himself, changes his garments, worships, and eats (…‭זחתשיז‬ ‭הזהי־תיב‬ ‭אביו‬ ‭ותלמש‬ ‭ףלחיו‬ ‭ךםיו‬ ‭ץחדיז‬ ‭ץךאהמ‬ ‭ךןך‬ ‭םקין‬ ‭לבאיו‬). David's servants are perplexed by his actions, noting that David fasted and wept while the child was alive (‭ךבתו‬ ‭תמי‬ ‭יח‬ ‭רליה‬ ‭רובצב‬). This response implies that weeping occurs before washing but it is difficult to ascertain that David weeping over the child in 2 Sam. 12.20 is the sole impetus for washing in v. 21, whereas the causality between ‭הבב‬ and ‭ץחך‬ in Gen. 43.30b-31a is more pronounced. The examples from Exodus and 2 Samuel provide little, if any, understanding towards an elucidation of the act of face-washing contained in Gen. 43.31a.9

Extra-biblical witnesses do not provide significant insights toward interpreting ‭וינפ‬ ‭ץחךיו‬. The attestations of šmn rḥṢ from the recovered eighth-century Samaria ostraca likely have no bearing on the discussion at hand.10 Among the Qumran manuscript evidence, the Temple Scroll from Cave 11 contains ‭ץחך‬ but these attestations do not describe a washing of the face.11 Finally, I shall note the description of Aseneth washing her face in the Hellenistic composition Joseph and Aseneth.12 In Jos. Asen. 14.12, Aseneth receives a commandment from a divine messenger to wash her face and hands in ‘living water’ (‭καì‬ ‭νίψαι‬ ‭τò‬ ‭πρόσωπόν‬ ‭σου‬ ‭καì‬ ‭τας‬ ‭χεΐράς‬ ‭σου‬ ‭ΰδατι‬ ‭ζῶντι‬), which she fulfils in 14.15 (‭καì‬ ‭ενίψατο‬ ‭τάς‬ ‭χεΐρας‬ ‭αùτής‬ ‭καì‬ ‭τò‬ ‭πρόσωπον‬ ‭αùτής‬ ‭ΰδατι‬ ‭ζῶντι‬).13 It is difficult, however, to infer that this account offers any insight into the biblical description of Joseph washing his face. Aseneth washing her face is performed within a series of actions that initiates a process of proselytization; in contrast, nowhere in the Joseph Story (in any source or layer) is the impression made that Joseph experiences conversion at any point after he washes his face in Gen. 43.31a.

sec.title: Face-Washing in Ancient Egyptian Literature
sec.p: The lack of biblical and extra-biblical witnesses of an Israelite explicitly washing his or her face prompts us to consider the Egyptian context of the Joseph Story. The Israelite author has gone to great lengths to demonstrate Joseph's assimilation in Egypt before the brothers’ arrival.14 The multiple allusions to Egypt suggest that the Israelite narrator was familiar with the land and the customs of its people, but to what degree this narrator objectively portrays actual Egyptian practices—and how accurate his sources are—remains a scholarly debate.15 Still, the question of whether or not a recovered Egyptian parallel can shed any insight into the motif of face-washing in Gen. 43.31a remains to be explored. Recovered reliefs from ancient Egyptian temples depict the ritual act of purification of pouring water over the head of an individual.16 Among the inscriptional evidence, three recovered sources from Egypt that predate the (Yahwist's) Joseph Story, which I date before the post-exilic period, are noteworthy for containing descriptions of washing the face. These sources contain iʿj ḥr, which represents the act of face-washing.17

(1) Three utterances from the Pyramid Texts of the Old Kingdom (2686-2181 bce) describe the washing of a pharaoh's face during his journey through the afterworld. In an utterance for Teti (2323-2291 bce), divine beings—male and female—wash Teti's face:18

disp-quote.p: The face of Teti has been washed by the gods, male and female: Imseti, Hapi, Duamutef, and Qebehsenuef (have washed) the right side of Teti, which is Horus; Djenderu-bark-striker, at the fore of his two papyrus columns, Nephthys, and Eyes-Forward, the left side of Teti, which is Seth. (PT 359 §601)

sec.p: The other two references to face-washing are found in utterances composed for Pepi II (2246-2152 bce):

disp-quote.p: You have been greeted by Sokar, Pepi Neferkare, and your face has been washed by Great Beard. (PT 682 §2042)

They have come having gotten for you the clean waters from their father, that they may cleanse you, that they may cleanse you with natron, Pepi Neferkare. You shall lift the sky with your hand and lay down the earth with your foot. Let cool water be poured at this Pepi Neferkare's gateway and the face of every god will be washed. (PT 685 §§2066–67)

sec.p: These three utterances present the motif of face-washing as a ritual in the afterlife performed by one deity for another as a greeting during a (deified) pharaoh's ascent through the afterworld (in §§2066–67, it could be suggested that the gods washing themselves is essential for Pepi's passage). The motif of face-washing as a greeting is difficult to apply to Gen. 43.31a for at least three reasons: first, if washing the face signifies a greeting in the Joseph Story, then I would expect this act to occur during the initial encounter between the brothers in Genesis 42; second, there are no active deities in Genesis 42–44; third, in the Pyramid Texts, the act of face-washing is performed within a divine council; in contrast, Joseph washes his face in seclusion from others.

(2) The epic commonly known as The Tale of Sinuhe (c. 1800 bce) contains a single attestation of iʿ ḥr in line 55 (Pap. Berlin 3022). Alan Gardiner opines that the literal sense of ‘washing the face’ is awkward and, through an emendation, proposes a metaphorical reading:19

disp-quote.p: 54 A curber of horns is he, a weakener of hands; his enemies
55 cannot marshall their ranks. Vengeful [iʿ ḥr; emend to iʿ ib] is he, a smasher of foreheads; none can stand
56 in his neighbourhood. Long of stride is he, destroying the fugitive;
57 there is no ending for any that turns his back to him.20

sec.p: If the text is to be read metaphorically, revenge is difficult to apply to Genesis 42–43. When Joseph recognizes his brothers, he does not harbour any thoughts of revenge against them. Joseph's scheme to confine Simeon in Gen. 42.24b is perhaps vengeful, but at the resolution of the narrative Joseph emphatically does not demonstrate a grudge against his brothers (Gen. 50.15–16).21

(3) In the eighth-century bce Triumph Stela of Piye (Pi'ankhy), recovered from a sanctuary at present day Gebel Barkal, Sudan,22 line 102 contains a reference to face-washing. Here, Piye is directed to wash his face in the River of Nun:

disp-quote.p: 101 His majesty proceeded to the camp, which was on the west of ʿItj: His purification was performed. He was cleansed in
102 the pool of Kebeh. He washed his face in the river of Noun, where Reʿ washes his face.23

sec.p: Purification is explicitly stated as the rationale for Piye washing his face in a body of water.24 It might be noteworthy that Piye and Joseph are foreigners who are elevated in Egypt, but the similarities likely end with this point. If purification can be transposed from the description in line 102 of the Stela on to Gen. 43.31a, then a question remains: What is Joseph purifying himself from? For reasons stated above, I remain hesitant to read Gen. 43.31a as an act of purification.

In the above examples from the Pyramid Texts, Sinuhe, and the Triumph Stela, I noted illustrations of face-washing that may offer an explanation for ‭וינפץחדיו‬ in Gen. 43.31a. Three (in addition to any other possible) attestations certainly do not allow for the conclusion that a ritual described within this sample of Egyptian literature directly influenced a half-verse in Genesis. The sample size may even be reduced when accessibility is considered. Even if Sinuhe was in wide circulation, the lexical difficulty of the single reference to face-washing remains. An Israelite would likely have to see Piye's Triumph Stela first-hand (in Lower Nubia) and the Pyramid Texts would have been inaccessible to many people. These recovered witnesses, however, suggest that face-washing circulated among a variety of contexts and projected a variety of images over an extended period of time in Egypt. The Israelite author who placed the Joseph Story in its Egyptian context partially relied on this particular literary motif to strengthen his presentation of an Egyptianized Joseph and contrast Joseph with his Hebrew brothers.

sec.title: An Israelite Use of a Foreign Motif
sec.p: In the Joseph Story, there are many allusions to Egypt and reports of its cultic practices. I suggest that the terse, yet unique, detail of face-washing in Gen. 43.31a is properly accounted for by the Egyptian background of the Joseph Story. Joseph washing his face maintains the fabrication that he is an Egyptian official. This Israelite author juxtaposes Joseph performing this local act in v. 31a with the report in vv. 31b-32 that the Egyptians considered eating with Hebrews an abomination. To heighten the fiction of Joseph as an Egyptian high official, the Israelite author writes ‭וינפץחדיו‬ in the second—and not the first—encounter between the brothers.

But this description raises another question: With what does Joseph wash his face? We should expect that Joseph washes his face with water. As suggested in the multiple descriptions of a host bringing out water for his guests (J) or in ritual bathing (P; H), water is important for washing in Israel.25 Water, however, is not mentioned in Gen. 43.31a.26 The intentional omission of water in Gen. 43.31a is suggested by the recovered Egyptian witnesses. Washing in water is common to Egypt and Israel but the above Egyptian witnesses suggest that washing in water in Egypt conveys a ritualistic and mystifying power that is observed within the Egyptian cult. In contrast, in the Yahwistic cult, water retains its capacity as a sacred and ritualistic disinfectant but is mostly stripped of significant occult powers.

Whereas the Israelite author reports Egyptian realia to present an authentic story of Joseph and his brothers in Egypt, Gen. 43.31a betrays this author's cultic sensibilities. For this author, Joseph's fidelity to Yhwh must not be ambiguous and Joseph, despite his assimilation as an Egyptian, cannot be portrayed as washing his face with water in Egypt due to its local cultic significance. In whatever manner an Israelite author may have understood or had access to Egyptian ritual customs, I stress an important point: any source (or compositional layer) of the Joseph Story should not be expected to reproduce actual Egyptian customs because the Israelite author, especially a devotee of Yhwh, was not interested in accurately portraying such customs when they conflicted with his own cultic (specifically, Yahwistic) ideologies and practices. In this article, I suggest that the rare and laconic description of face-washing in Gen. 43.31a was determined by the Egyptian location of the Joseph Story. An Israelite author delicately alludes to a foreign motif in his presentation of a credible narrative set in another part of the world.

‭ץחך‬ is not to be confused with other verbs for washing, especially ‭ףטש‬ or ‭סככ‬ (for a full discussion, see ThWAT, VII, pp. 482–90). The distinction between these verbs is clear in P, with the strongest example contained in Lev. 15.11: anyone touched by one with a genital discharge (‭בו‬) without thoroughly rinsing (‭ףטש‬) his hands with water, laundering (‭סככ‬) his clothes, and bathing (‭ץחך‬) in water remains unclean until the evening. Additionally, any wooden vessel touched by the ‭בו‬ is to be rinsed (‭ףטש‬) in water (v. 12; in the administration of the ‭תאטח‬ in P, a bronze vessel used to boil the sacrifice is also rinsed [‭ףטש‬; Lev. 6.21 et 28]). The lexical distinction between washing (‭ץחך‬) oneself in water and washing (‭סככ‬) their own article of clothing is explicit elsewhere in Priestly legislation: concerning a scale-diseased person at the time of purification (Lev. 14.8, 9); concerning one who contacted (abnormal or normal) genital discharges (15.5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 13, 16, 18, 21, 22, 27); after priests release the scapegoat (16.26) and discard the remains of the ‭תאטח‬ offering (16.28) when atonement is made for the Tabernacle; after the preparation of a bovine victim for a mixture used for purification purposes (Num. 19.7, 8); and for the clean person (‭ךהטה‬) who attends to anyone in contact or in close proximity to a corpse or grave (19.19). In H, bathing oneself in water and washing their clothes is required after the consumption of a carcass (Lev. 17.15–16).

In addition to the legislation cited above: Aaron and his sons are required to wash their hands and feet before entering the Tent of Meeting (Exod. 29.4; 30.18–21; 40.12, 30–32); upon their consecration as priests, Aaron and his sons are washed (Lev. 8.6); on the Day of Purgation, Aaron is instructed to bathe before and after he performs his high priestly duties (16.4, 24). Specifically within the Priestly corpus, the description of washing in water belongs in legal language (Gesetzessprache) but is absent, and thus implied, in non-legal texts (cf. Exod. 29.17; Lev. 9.14). See Karl Elliger, Leviticus (HAT, 4; Tübingen: Mohr, 1966), pp. 187–88 n. 53. In H, one who contacts a swarming object (‭ץךש‬) or an unclean human must wash in water before partaking in the ‭םישךק‬ meal (Lev. 22.5–6). I shall discuss the relevance of this H legislation to Gen. 43.31a below.

Although not as extensive as the Priestly corpus, J also distinguishes between ‭ץחך‬ and ‭םככ‬: the former refers to bodily washing and the latter describes the washing of an article of dress: ‘garment’ (‭שוכל‬; Gen. 49.11) and ‘clothes’ (‭הלמש‬; Exod. 19.10, 14).

Classically, the visits in Gen. 42–43 are doublets of the same visit. See Julius Wellhausen, Die Composition des Hexateuchs und die historichen Bücher (Berlin: G. Reimer, 1899), pp. 55–58. This source-critical solution to Gen. 42–43, however, presents serious difficulties concerning narrative continuity in the classical documents, J and E. In the present study I employ the source-critical assignment of the two visits to Egypt (Gen. 42.1–45.28) to J offered by Baruch Schwartz in his ‘J and E in the Joseph Saga’ (unpublished paper presented at the Annual Meeting of the Society of Biblical Literature, New Orleans, November 2009). Schwartz argues for an unprecedented source-critical solution to identifying J and E in Gen. 37–50. For other literary reconstructions that maintain the unity of Gen. 42–44, see Donald B. Redford, A Study of the Biblical Story of Joseph (Genesis 37–50) (VTSup, 20; Leiden: E.J. Brill, 1970), p. 178; Claus Westermann, Genesis (BKAT, 1/3; Neukirchen–Vluyn: Neukirchener Verlag, 1982), p. 108 (= Genesis 37–50: A Continental Commentary [trans. John J. Scullion; Minneapolis: Fortress Press, 2002], pp. 118–20); Erhard Blum, Die Komposition der Vätergeschichte (WMANT, 57; Neukirchen–Vluyn: Neukirchener Verlag, 1984), pp. 231–34. In principle, I agree that Gen. 42–44 is not a doublet but rather a unified narrative that reports two consecutive visits of Joseph's brothers to Egypt.
Jacob Milgrom, Leviticus 17–22: A New Translation with Introduction and Commentary (AB, 3A; New York: Doubleday, 2000), p. 1854.

I shall briefly note the description contained in 2 Kgs 8.15. Hazael dips a ‭ךככמ‬ in water and spreads (‭שךב‬) it over the Aramaean king Ben-hadad's face. The causal relationship between Hazael's actions and Ben-hadad's death is unclear but this account does not depict an act of face-washing and will not be further considered in this study.

The meaning of šmn rḥṣ is disputed and rḥṣ in the ostraca may contain a meaning foreign to the biblical corpus. For the vocalization of šemen rāḥūṣ (‘washed oil’) and its identification as ‘pure oil’, see Aḥituv, Ketav, p. 262. For a discussion on šmn rḥṣ as a food product, see Victor Sasson, ‘ŠMN RḤṢ in the Samaria Ostraca’, JSS 26 (1981), pp. 1–5.

When a direct object is included with the verb ‭ץחך‬, the instructions to wash are specific to the extremities (11Q19 26.10: ‭וילגך תאו ויךי תא ץחךו‬) and flesh (45.16: ‭םייח םימב וךךשב לוכ תא ץחךו‬).

For discussion on Joseph and Aseneth as a likely product of Egyptian Judaism, see John J. Collins, Between Jerusalem and Athens: Jewish Identity in the Hellenistic Diaspora (Grand Rapids, MI: Eerdmans, 2nd edn, 2000), pp. 103–108. The textual history of Joseph and Aseneth remains disputed, with some commentators favouring the longer recension as reconstructed in Christoph Burchard, Joseph und Aseneth (PVTG, 5; Leiden: E.J. Brill, 2003), pp. 70–337. For an English translation of Joseph and Aseneth, see OTP, II, pp. 202–47. The text and versification in the present study are from Burchard, Joseph und Aseneth, pp. 182, 184.
Commentators generally agree that Joseph and Aseneth was originally composed in Greek. lxx Gen. 43.31a (καì νιαμενos τò πρóσωπoν) is as laconic as its mt counterpart.

Schwartz, ‘Joseph Saga’, establishes a clear indicator of this assimilation by noting that J never has Joseph referring to his deity as Yhwh but rather Elohim. In Gen 39.9, Joseph asks his Egyptian master's wife, ‘How then could I do this great wickedness, and sin against ‭םיהלא‬?’ For Israelites referring to their deity as ‭םיהלא‬ when conversing with foreigners, see John Skinner, A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on Genesis (Edinburgh: T. & T. Clark, 2nd edn, 1930), p. 458; Nahum M. Sarna, Genesis=Be-reshit: the Traditional Hebrew Text with New JPS Translation (Philadelphia: Jewish Publication Society, 1989), p. 273; Joel S. Baden, J, E, and the Redaction of the Pentateuch (FAT, 68; Tübingen: Mohr Siebeck, 2009), p. 216.

Specific to the Joseph Story portraying Egyptian customs, a positive appraisal on the accuracy of the Joseph Story is presented in Jozef Vergote, Joseph en Égypte; Genèse chap. 37–50 à la lumière des études égyptologiques récentes (OBL, 3; Louvain: Publications Univertaires, 1959). For the opposing argument that the Israelite author ‘was not so well acquainted with Egypt’, see Redford, Biblical Story of Joseph, pp. 189–253 (at 242). For two recent studies, see Lisbeth Fried, ‘Why Did Joseph Shave?’, BAR 33 (2007), pp. 36–41, and Bernd U. Schipper, ‘Gen 41.42 and the Egyptian Background to the Investiture of Joseph’, RB 118 (2011), pp. 331–38. Fried scrutinizes the description of Joseph shaving himself in anticipation of meeting Pharaoh in Gen. 41.14 and concludes that this detail is compliant with Egyptian hygiene requirements and preparatory measures before taking an Egyptian priestly office. Schipper examines a seventh-century bce Ionian inscription recovered from Asia Minor that reports an Egyptian pharaoh conferring a high position upon a foreigner.

For a discussion of Egyptian reliefs from the New Kingdom (1550-1069 bce), Saite (685-525 bce), Ptolemaic (332-30 bce), and early Roman (30 bce–100 ce) periods depicting the pouring of water over the head of a pharaoh, crown prince, dead person, priestess and priest for temple service, and its influence on the Graeco-Roman worship of Isis and Sarapis, see Robert A. Wild, Water in the Cultic Worship of Isis and Sarapis (EPRO, 87; Leiden: E.J. Brill, 1981), pp. 145–46, 254–55.

For iʾ ḥr (jʾj ḥr) (‘Gesicht waschen’), see Rainer Hannig, Ägyptisches Wörterbuch, Bd. 1: Altes Reich und Erste Zwischenzeit (Kulturgeschichte der antiken Welt, 98; Mainz am Rhein: P. von Zabern, 2003), p. 37; Hannig, Ägyptisches Wörterbuch, Bd. 2: Mittleres Reich und Zweite Zwischenzeit, Teil 1 (Kulturgeschichte der antiken Welt, 112; Mainz am Rhein: P. von Zabern, 2006), p. 102. Due to the accessibility of secondary literature, I have restricted this study to three sources, but shall here note two other attestations of ‘Gesicht waschen’ in Hannig, Wörterbuch. First, in inscriptions from Siut dated to the First Intermediate Period (2181-2055 bce), see the probable attestation in Siut III, line 29 to ‘sein Gesicht wäscht’ in Hellmut Brunner, Die Texte aus den Gräbern der Herakleopolitenzeit von Siut mit Übersetzung und Erläuterungen (ÄF, 5; Glückstadt/ New York: J.J. Augustin, 1937), pp. 17–19, 46. Piye washing his face in a body of water is one among other purification rituals described in the Triumph Stela. Line 97 contains the purification of a place with natron and lines 110, 141–42 describe a king undertaking purification with a divine oath. See also Piye's instruction to his army before their entry into Egypt in line 12: ‘Quand vous arrivez dans Thèbes; devant Ipet-sout, entrez dans l'eau, purifiez-vous dans le fleuve, habilliezvous de lin pur; posez l'arc, déposez la flèche’ (in Grimal, Stèle, p. 26).

In addition to the above references cited from J, P, and H, other descriptions of washing (‭ץחך‬) in water are in D (Deut. 23.11 [et 12]); Ezek. 16.4, 9. Judith contains two descriptions of the heroine washing in water in 10.3 (καì περιεκλνσατo τo σωμα νδατι) and 12.7 (κα` επαπτíζετo εν τη παρεμβoλη επì τηs πηγηs τoν νδατos). Descriptions of washing in a river are elsewhere in Dtr (‭ץחך‬ and ‭לבט‬ in 2 Kgs 5.10–14) and in both recensions of Tob. 6.2 (lxxBA: τò δε παιδαριoν κατεβη περικλνσασαι; lxxS: και κατεβητò παιδíoν περινíασαι τoνs πòδαs εís τòν Tíγριν πoταμóν).

Gen. 19.2 is the other notable exception in J. Situated in Sodom, Lot invites the ‭םיכאלמ‬ to stay and wash their feet but there is no mention of water. The lack of water may be an intentional omission (cf. Gen. 13.10 [J]: ‭הקשמ הלכ יכ ןךךיה ךככ לכ תא אךיו‬) that foreshadows the inhospitality of the Sodomites against the sojourners in Gen. 19.
